awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Thermal-Noise-Based Mechanisms for Intracellular Motion, with Application to Engineered Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The emerging ability to engineer the simultaneous directed motion of large numbers of small particles, from micrometer size down to large molecules, will have tremendous impact in diverse areas of medicine, electronics and bio-materials. Such directed motion is an integral part of normal intracellular function, where motor proteins convert ambient electrochemical potentials and random thermal agitation into motion and act as tiny cargo haulers. This project will learn from and build upon these biological mechanisms, to create a framework for facilitating robust and efficient collective motion of large numbers of microscale and submicroscale particles.  Innovative instrumentation created for this project will probe forces acting on motor proteins. Realization of engineered motion of microscale particles will lead to new materials for electronics and biomedicine. The new analytical techniques will find use in related studies, such as on the role of cellular transport malfunctions in disease.
 
This project will employ the following two Brownian ratchet based approaches to obtain robust and efficient mechanisms for transporting cargo at the microscale: (i) shape optical fields to accurately realize desired potential energy landscapes that enable Brownian ratchet mechanisms where noise enables useful work, and (ii) understand how biological components  such as motor proteins and microtubules employ Brownian ractchets to achieve motion, and use these constructs for moving engineered cargo. Optical ratchet mechanisms will be realized using modern control techniques. For studying bio-protein motion, modern controls and systems tools will be used to obtain probes at least an order of magnitude faster than the present state-of-the-art. New modes of investigating motor proteins using optical traps will include tension and force clamps, which will facilitate unambiguous interpretation of molecular motion. Innovative open- and closed-loop control laws for optical force fields will be derived to realize Brownian ratchet based directed motion.

por.por_cntn:
Noise is typically considered detrimental. However, at the small-scale noise can be harnessed for productive purposes. In this project Brownian ratchet mechanisms for transport of particles at the micron scale were investigated.  A theoretical paradigm with a focus on optimality with respect to transport performance especially - time-to-destination and energy efficiency is developed. Another outcome of the project is high bandwidth instrumentation for investigation of matter at the small scale where noise effects are particularly significant. The project also investigated transport of a single particle from one well to another well over a barrier. The wells and the barriers were realized using optical-fields with energy scales that are small enough to be relevant to the physics at the nanometer and smaller scales and pertinent to single molecule behavior. The energetics realized at a scale where the ambient noise can affect the transport between wells significantly. Detailed experiments realized have shown that the theoretical limits on the energetics of the transport can be approached experimentally. Thorough analysis of the non-idealities in the experimentation and the resulting analysis of the deviation form the assumptions made in theoretical models further illustrate that the experimental realizations match the models well. These studies have shed insights between information theory, feedback control and thermodynamics. Under the project a new course was developed that emphasized the role of noise in engineered and biological systems. Considerable outreach to the relevant communities of controls, information theory and biology was made and results disseminated via publications and talks.
